review_text: Between 1945 and 1975, New York City functioned like an island of social democracy in the United States: free universal higher education, accessible health care, free or affordable day care. Due to deindustrialization, suburbanization, and economic crisis, though, by the mid 70s the city faced declining tax revenue and increasing expenditures, and was forced to borrow extensively from banks. This effectively ended the city's social democracy, putting bankers in charge to write the most important

The financial crisis of New York City in the mid-seventies was a microcosm of the crisis of postwar liberalism (Europeans read Social Democracy). New York city was on the verge of bankruptcy and state and federal government including the Ford Administration decided not to bail NYC out and left the city to sort out its problems of a declining tax base fleeing to suburbs and large pockets of poverty. This was a moment when austerity became the default pattern for the city. The now all too familiar

Naomi Klein has said that when her book “The Shock Doctrine” came out, that one place many have said she left out, was what happened in New York City during the 70s. She refers to this work in her latest book and insisting that this does a fine job of telling the story and she isn’t wrong.

Phillips-Fein traces the origins of the crisis back to the 60s. Between the late 60s and the mid-70s, half a million jobs disappeared from the city, meaning that more people were in need of the city services. G

Do you ever wonder why our pundits blather endlessly about deficits? Has it ever vexed you how Amazon can pay zero federal taxes while receiving offers from dozens of municipalities worth billions? Or perhaps you are curious why in New York, one of the wealthiest locales on earth, thousands of people live without homes?

This book is an ideal place to begin an education on these matters. It charts the development and agonizing consequences of New York's fiscal crisis of the 1970s. But more than t
If balancing municipal budgets isn't your thing, then you can probably skip this one.
This book is so good she turned fiscal policy into a political thriller.

Feckless, performatively woke mayor skips town chasing after long-shot presidential campaign; the most dire fiscal crisis the city has ever seen ensues. Is New York's history repeating itself?

This book deserves an adaptation in the style of The Big Short. Phillips-Fein's account is driven by both personality and policy, portraying the stories of those thrust into positions of great, unelected responsibility alongside with the consequences of their decisions.

You will find both an accessible break

Good telling of the events that created the NYC fiscal crisis in 1970s and the austerity policies that followed and their consequences to the city.

The important thing to realize is that while the budget cuts improved the city's revenue and credit standings, they did not improve the lives of the people living in the city. The outcomes would go against the very rhetoric that was used to push the budget cuts: things like poverty, sickness, unemployment, and crime all increased, not decreased, show

Not only an amazing read on a specific and important era in New York's history, but also an important reminder for the Left to see how far we've fallen. This represents the decline of the New Deal and the rise of Neo-Liberalism that we have to reckon with now.
The author is less neutral than I prefer in history books, but aside from that, it was good. Covers an interesting period with a lot of primary sources, but from enough distance to have some insight.

An enjoyable analysis of the financial problems that NYC faced during the 1970s as it went to the cliff of bankruptcy. This historical tackles deep economic assumptions and lessons learned from the crises, avoiding blame on any single cause (unlike the politicians of the time, who searched for easy scapegoats).

This is a human story, and economic story, and a political story. . . Good stuff!

This was interesting, but a little too focused on the small-ball aspects of new York's 1970s fiscal crisis. Maybe I just wish this had been part of a larger fabric of the 60s/70s urban crises and the subsequent conservative insurgency.

Fear City is a rather mixed bag. The first two parts--which cover how New York City got into a precarious financial situation in the 1970s and how it secured the necessary financing to avoid default--are well researched and excellent. However, the remainder of the book is far less compelling. In this portion, Phillips-Fein uses cherry picked examples to demonstrate the difficulties caused by the City's austerity policies and seems to contend that default may have been a better alternative. I just heard a great interview of the author on "Your Call" with Rose Aguilar on KALW radio.http://kalw.org/programs/your-call#st...

Fear City is a fascinating look at New York City's fiscal crisis in the 1970s. Phillips-Fein is a great storyteller who synthesized a vast amount of data to generate an exceptionally well-organized and written documentary. The detail may be a bit excessive. But every chapter and subsection flows smoothly. She has a liberal bias. Although she is subtle in focusing on the crisis, her views mean that Republicans, including Donald Trump, emerge from the pages as villains. The story of the crisis the
Good NYC history, full of infuriating anecdotes about cutting education and health funding. Also, Ed Koch seems like a pretty big jerk.

'Fear City' is a thorough overview of a significant turning point in the history of New York City and the United States, and the West, in general—the rise of austerity politics. The decade of the 1970s saw moves away from the Great Society model of government (which, abstractly, emphasized the responsibility of the government to provide services to its citizens that promoted equity) to the vision of government that is so familiar to us today, that of a limited government whose role it is to keep

Books about financial crises shouldn’t be this exciting. Books about financial crises that happened 40 years shouldn’t be this exciting. But, somehow, Kim Phillips-Fein has achieved the impossible. One would think a book dealing with such a serious and complicated subject would read like dry homework, but Phillips-Fein has managed to tell the story in a riveting way. I don’t want to say that I couldn’t wait to put this book down, but it most definitely is a page turner.

I read Kim Phillips-Fein's "Invisible Hands: The Businessmen's Crusade Against the New Deal" several years ago, and "Fear City" is a perfect complement that likewise enriches our understanding of the collapse of the social democratic consensus and the rise of neoliberalism. In both books, she astutely observes the build-up of causes, reordering of power, and individual and collective actions that, over time, effect a shift in economic paradigm. As "Invisible Hands" tracked the evolution of conse

Between the 1930s and the late 1960s, the people and elected officials of New York City created the nearest thing to St. Augustine's City of God on Earth -- a city where everyone could get an education from kindergarden through PhD without cost, not as a charity but as a right. A city where municipal hospitals and clinics ensured that people could get affordable medical care -- not free, but not bankrupting either. A city where day care was available, immediate, and inexpensive, freeing up thous

This is an important book that tells a story that must be remembered. In the mid-1970s, New York came close to bankruptcy as a consequence partly from poor financial decisions on the part of city government, but largely because postwar government policies and racist attitudes subsidized and drove the move of industry and the middle class to the suburbs, decimating the city's tax base. Yes, it had a lot of obligations from its social policies, which included tuition-free colleges, good schools, f

Fear City - New York's Fiscal Crisis and the Rise of Austerity Politics covers in detail the NYC fiscal crisis of the 1970s. The crisis is told against the backdrop of the postwar liberal Ameria (i.e. LBJ's Great Society) and the mismanagement of city funds by successive NYC mayors. The real story, however, is the closed-door compromises that catapult NYC from the "bastion state of welfare" into a city of vast inequality and devoted to corporate interests.

I ordered this book when it became clear during the coronavirus crisis that New York City would be confronting major fiscal challenges. I wanted to better understand the 1970s crisis — the factors that led to the city’s fiscal problems, what happened on the ground during the worst of the crisis, how the city emerged and the event’s larger significance. I thought this book delivered on these questions, so I recommend it.

Excellent account of the 1970s fiscal crisis in New York. Tragic how the belief in government in the 50s and 60s to solve social issues, coupled with emerging social justice movements, were hollowed out by industry leaving NYC. Just as minority groups were gaining some parity with whites, the money was pulled out from under them under the guise of austerity. Having quality health care, access to education and decent paying jobs are not privileged demands; they are rights. The rich couch economic

We’re far enough from New York’s 1970s financial crisis that you can read Kim Phillips-Fein’s Pulitzer-winning history of it and then look around you and see in glass and steel the permanent transformations the crisis wrought. It’s a done deal.
Her argument is the financial crisis created the opening that forced New York’s Neoliberal turn. It voided the egalitarian social contract that had guided the city through its golden age from the 30s to the late 60s. The new arrangement took shape slowly b

Prior to the fiscal crisis, New York City had a very broad and generous social welfare system, from a robust network of municipal hospitals and clinics, free college education within the CUNY system, free/subsidized day care, etc. While imperfect, it was perhaps the closest a city came to bringing the ideals of the Great Society to life. To my knowledge, this book is easily the best history on the rolling back of these ideals and the programs that were put in place in an attempt to make these id

"Over time, this aggressive use of debt meant postponing more than just taxes: it meant delaying conflict, putting off political fights about New York City's welfare state." (44)

Starting at age thirteen, he labored at the paper factory with his father from 4 p.m. until midnight. (He saved money by rollerskating to and from school rather than taking publi

This is a magnificent book, one of the best I read this year. If I told you it was a history of New York City's descent into fiscal hell, and its attempts to avoid bankruptcy in the 1970s, you might logically respond, "Um, no thanks. Are you insane?" Instead, it's a clear, steady retelling of what turns out to be something of a thrilling ride. Phillips-Fein turns a story based essentially on municipal bonds, budget-cutting, and inter-government wrangling into something akin to a page-turner.

A good chronicle of the nyc fiscal crisis and what it felt like to be in the city in 1975. The biggest weakness is the book's clear left wing, and mostly unconvincing, tilt as pre-crisis nyc is painted a triumph of post-war liberalism with the crisis simply being a means for a group of neoliberal elites to crush the order. The underlying causes of the crisis are somewhat shortchanged as the author largely blames outside forces eg the failure of state and federal governments to give support or al

A necessary corrective to many people’s romantic notions of the 70s & 80s city (myself included). For all the creative freedom and inspiring resistance, the staggering amount of public misery is difficult to comprehend.

This is an excellent case study of how the groundwork for our current national economic problems, in terms of income inequality and lack of public services, began in the austerity forced on New York by Gerald Ford and his cronies, Donald Rumsfeld & Dick Cheney— an austerity furthe

Kim Phillips-Fein does an excellent job laying out how bankers, big business, and the federal government used New York City as its test case for what they'd eventually do to the country as a whole. Neoliberalism and harsh austerity was imposed on the Big Apple before it took its hold from sea to shining sea. The initial financial mismanagement and benevolent overreach of a government, the flight of any outside help to keep things running, and the radical restructuring of public institutions to l

Even with all the intricate finance and budget talk that was introduced to save the city, the author keeps the narrative moving. That is no small feat as New York jumped through some complicated economic hoops to keep the city solvent. The political backdrop is interesting as it was a marker for the conservative ideological wave that would soon sweep the country. With the likes of Rumsfeld, Simon, Greenspan et al in the Gerald Ford camp, the intent was to strike a blow against liberalism. And al

Fear City is a thorough account of the near-bankruptcy of New York City in 1975, how the city was on the forefront of expanding health care, education, and other opportunities to lower class citizens following WWII, how overspending (relative to revenue) in the '60s led to banks not wanting to buy NYC bonds, and, crucially, how the Ford Administration (including characters like Donald Rumsfeld, Dick Cheney, and Alan Greenspan) saw the crisis as an opportunity to force the city to close hospitals

The fiscal crisis of the 1970s is one of those stories that was all consuming and then quickly forgotten. Kim Phillips-Fein does a good job telling us the story but is too focused on the political aspects than the human ones. There are several great anecdotes about the human aspects but when we're about to get into them we're dashed off to something the mayor is doing or something in DC.

I enjoyed reading about how the city got to its point of collapse and how the crisis was botched but after the

A detailed analysis of the fiscal crisis in New York City in the 1970’s but still missing some big pieces of the puzzle. There was little discussion about teachers, education and the Board of Ed as an entrenched political machine and the issue of bussing. Also, there was little discussion of the banks red lining practices in many neighborhoods throughout the City. I think this book also needs a mew forward in light of the pandemic and protests to defund the police. Finally, I would have liked a

This well researched book looks at the financial crisis in New York City. Phillips-Fein organized the material according to the origins of the crisis, the crisis itself, and its legacies. He exposes the flaws created by the public sector and the inability of the citizen to change policies that affect their daily lives. She does not presume to have all the answers, but she did a fine job defining and highlighting the problems. Philips-Fein is a historian and teaches at the Gallatin School of Indi

I bought this book because this covers the three years that I lived in NYC. I lived in the West Village and worked at The Improv at 44th and 9th and a recording studio on 57th Street. I didn't have kids in public school, didn't work for the city or go to the city college or need a city hospital, and didn't live in the boroughs, so the fiscal crisis didn't affect me personally, as it's described in the book.

The author explains very clearly and with very engaging prose how New York got to the poin

A history with background information and blow-by-blows of the machinations behind New York City's near-bankruptcy in the 1970s sounds like it should be the stuff of dry economics texts, but I found this utterly riveting. I learned a lot that I didn't know anything about, including that Gerald Ford wasn't just a stopgap of a President, but played an active part in creating economic conditions and the Ayn Rand-worshiping elements of government that we're dealing with today. This isn't just about

This book is a blow-by-blow account of New York's mid-1970s fiscal crisis. Although the author's perspective is very left-wing and pro-spending, she accumulates a set of facts showing that the city's finances were out of control before the crisis. For example, she admits that in John Lindsay's first term (1965-69) "the city's spending on social services and welfare had doubled" and "Health and hospital spending had risen by more than 50 percent." (p. 36).

In the last few chapters, the author sug

I am too young to have witnessed New York City in the 1970's, but when I picture it in my mind it is something like a combination of Taxi Driver, Dog Day Afternoon and Summer of Sam. I see a city that is overcrowded, filthy, full of crime and falling apart. New York is no longer falling apart or overrun with crime, but rather faces the problems of over affluence, becoming a city decreasingly accessible in many parts except to those in the upper middle class or higher. If economic policy isn't of interest to you, then this is probably not your book.

A thorough and useful review of the near-bankruptcy of NYC in the mid 70's. The author strives to use the events around this time to explore the notion of post WWII liberalism, and social policy...and how, at least in this example, the policies weren't viable. The author also then does a good job showing how the decisions made during this era (austerity, and then pro-growth policies) were direct contributors to the

Very good narrative from a purely chronological standpoint. Phillips-Fein captures just how much was lost in the viciousness of the budget cuts imposed by downtown business and Washington alike, and the new neoliberal city (and country) that emerged in its wake. The book could have done with some more examination of just how and why New York's tax base was so drastically shattered in the preceding decades (white flight, suburban housing and highway subsidization, etc.), but she does a good job e

Excellent! A clear and compelling examination of a complicated moment in New York City. I was especially impressed with the way community activism and and government negotiations were woven together throughout, with brief but effective nods to how the fiscal crisis and the response to it shaped the perception of New York and normalized austerity and privatization throughout the country. It's also a powerful critique of the fiscal crisis' legacy in creating the shiny but deeply unequal city of 20

Absolutely mind expanding story about this piece of history that I knew nothing about previously. The connection to the present day debates is also fascinating and troubling, and the detail that the author has researched on the characters and the narrative was really excellent. As a nerd, one thing that bothered me was her lack of relative costs, rarely using inflation adjusted amounts or percentages to show size. Highly recommend for anyone with an interest in economics, political narsatives, o

If this is a topic that interests you, then I'd recommend this book... It's well written and detailed. I didn't read all the way through because it's really not my cup of tea, but I read the first couple of chapters and the author sets the stage well. She makes this feel more like a story than just shoving facts in your face, but I still got a little tired reading it. Blocky text just does that to me. But I do really appreciate that the author actually cited her sources - which is a must for top

A lot of stories and characters, very little analysis. I would have liked to have seen more about "austerity politics," and more connections made with current fiscal crises and their attempted resolutions, but what I did learn from the book is that the New York bankruptcy was averted through compromises that seem like they would be rare today, so perhaps those connections are just not there to be made.

Who says liberal is a dirty word ?

Meticulous research and engaged prose of a time most people hold no fond memories for. Being born and raised in Brooklyn and a proud grad of public school including CUNY makes me partial to Kim's subjects and her views. Like many I left NYC in the 80's but fate brought me back last year. Now after reading Fear City I don't feel so foolish, it's not the same same city I left.

Phillips-Fein retells the story of the Fiscal Crisis in all of its complexity. She does so clearly and as objectively as possible, allowing the reader to get a firm grasp over the events and drawing their own opinions. I especially enjoyed the final chapter where she related the Crisis to the events that followed in the city, nationally and internationally.

Highly would recommend if you want a firm understanding of the beginning of austerity politics in the United States.

I picked this book up because it was a Pulitzer Prize finalist, which is a way I use to broaden my history, non-fiction reading beyond interesting titles. I really enjoyed it. Lots of food for thought. I'm fascinated with how things work, especially large things, large groups, large machines, large cities, and this book provided plenty of fuel for thought along those lines.

Also, I consumed this book as an audio book download, via my library's app, and it worked just fine in that format.

In Fear City Kim Phillips-Fein provides a penetrating look at the 1975 financial crisis of New York City. Conservatives launched an enduring narrative that the root causes were liberal excesses, unionization and out of control welfare for the poor. The fact that NYC did not control immigration or that it was a donor jurisdiction to federal coffers was dismissed. The dismantlement of key services to poorer residents exacerbated the class division that remains to this day.

An outstanding case study detailing an inequality-making soul-engineering experiment and the citizen-activists who fought against it: before hipsters, Sex and the City, Giuliani, Trump, and the gentrification of its working-class neighborhoods, post-WWII New York City was a social-democratic metropolis that became a testing ground for a new shock doctrine, the use of crisis to rationalize social spending cuts and remake the city into a corporate Disneyland. New York City: first in finance, media

Whip smart. Learned so much (that I’ve promptly forgotten). The book seems much kinder to Mayor Beame than its thesis would otherwise suggest. He was just a bureaucrat over matched by the situation. I left sympathetic to Beame, understanding the importance of unions in preserving civic life, and with a cautious eye looking at the parallels of the de Blasio administration with the Lindsay administration...

Ms. Phillips-Fein describes how the NY City fiscal crisis of the 1970's marked the beginning of even greater income inequality with remarkable clarity and perspective. This is the finest non-fiction book I've read this year, and I highly recommend it for anyone interested in NY City political history, or social economics in general.

Interesting study of when New York City began to turn the corner of economic sustainability. Prescient in that politicians, unions, agencies, and others had to make difficult decisions to keep the city afloat. So far, with nearly $20 trillion in debt and counting, the U.S. doesn't seem prepared to make similar difficult choices and could face a financially precarious future.

Interesting blow by blow of the causes and immediate results of New York's fiscal crisis. My only critique is that the book seemed to imply that the City could have taken a different approach to managing the crisis (i.e. not simply relied on budget cuts and austerity measures) but was disappointingly vague on what that might have looked like.

Phillips-Fein's book illuminates a forgotten New York, before corporate development was the primary aim of the city's government. She clearly outlines how tax dollars that had once supported social programs were instead given away to corporate interests, and how that change hollowed the city into one of haves and have-nots.

Excellent, excellent book. Makes a fiscal crisis riveting which is a coup and feels like a must read for New York City history fans especially those working for organizations that came out of this period, such as Prospect Park Alliance. Great perspective on the series of mayors Beame, Koch and what they were reacting against ie post World War II.

this Joker (2019) prequel whips ass!!



a genuine triumph from the academic community, providing enduring evidence that financial history can be interesting. a gripping blend of urban politics and economic tensions that unfolds before a grim backdrop of trash-filled, crumbling streets and burning brownstones. magnificent analytic work

A phenomenal and approachable take on NYC's flirtation with bankruptcy. I really enjoyed that Phillips-Fein showed how this crisis was more than just financial; it upended the relationship between government and citizen. A great read!

I’m trying to read more non-fiction this year and this was a good book. It was a good overview of NYC’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s and the rise of austerity politics. It was thorough but I still felt I was missing something. It might need to be re-read to see if I find that something missing.

Clear, factual account of how conservative, austerity/shock politics reshaped NYC during the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. Phillips-Fein touches briefly on the 1977 blackout, which led to the now discredited 'broken windows' policing policy, as well as the rise of Rudy Guiliani.

I think the first 100 pages of preamble were a bit slow and felt tacked on in a way. The rest of the book is at 4-5 star quality in terms of writing quality and drama. Good pairing with The Power Broker, for a nearly complete history of NYC.

Audiobook. An extremely informative and comprehensive look at near-bankruptcy of NYC in the mid-70s and the financial, political, and cultural impacts that still reverberate to today. Highly recommend

Magnificently researched, tough-but-fair retelling of one of the most significant (but little talked about) events in our past that directly impacts our government and society today. Phillips-Fein drives down to the most important details while keeping "the people" in the forefront.

Wow. I had no idea how little I cared about the fiscal crisis of New York until I read this book. That being said, it was interesting at parts and I did finish it. I can appreciate why others loved the book so much - it just wasn’t for me.

A VERY detailed view of NYC fiscal crisis of the 70s, ending with Mayor Beame's capitulation to austerity budgeting at the command of banking and business forces....and the blessing of the Ford Administration

A really well researched look into New York's financial crisis in the 1970s and its transition away from a "welfare state" when faced with near bankruptcy. The book did a good job presenting the events from multiple perspectives. The third section of the book was a bit weaker.

A lot of fascinating anecdotes and insight into how financial interests came to control American cities. Clear as well on the roots of cities' lack of services in federal government policy. Reads as a compelling sequel to The Power Broker.

This book did a very good job with a topic that could have been boring and dry. It never lagged and was able to deal with the minutia of committees and finance in an engaging manner.

I knew a lot of this before I started the book, but Kruse and Zelizer do a great job of weaving together the various threads that have put us where we are today. It was a breath of fresh air after reading so many books about historical topics by non-historians to read two proper professional historians provide structural context for events. By the time we get to Trump, they have laid out the various factors that produced him.

Although I can't think of a single bit of information here that I hadn't read elsewhere within the past year or two, Kruse has done a great job of compiling a comparatively concise history of the US in the past 45 years, using the date of Nixon's resignation as a starting point with just a little backtracking here and there. The focus of his history is on the ever-increasing "fault lines" or cracks/divisions when it comes to partisanship, race, gender, and economical. Very good presentation.

Look, I think this is going to be a really useful book in a couple of decades, but I lived through most of this and so the book felt more like a review than anything else -- I was hoping for more insight and analysis, I guess? Overview of the fault lines that have managed to polarize American Society, (starting with Watergate, citing the event as a tipping point in political demarcations). Analyzes fault lines along social, economic, gender and racial divides. Looks at the contributions of social media, legislation guided by discrimination and the blind spots of politicians, each of whom claims to be able to unite an America that seems content with its own malcontent.

A very accessible read that is well-sourced, which is to be expected from leading scholars. I like how the authors incorporated a variety of sources and cultural references to show how the fault lines impacted much more than the political landscape. The book offers a great overview of how America landed in its current situation. It took me a while to read only because I read the Kindle version, which always takes me much longer. There's nothing like a physical book.

This book is fantastic! I can not recommend it enough as a wonderful summary of US history from 1974 on, with emphasis on how we came to feel like such a divided nation. It is a very good big picture perspective that goes above and beyond the sometimes shortsighted “reporting” of the day that lacks important rooting in historical context. Go out and borrow or purchase this book.

A good overview of how politics has in someways always been deeply divided and how it has grown at an accelerated rated recently (in ways that should’ve been publicly predicted).
If you’re looking to try to understand the history of modern politics, this would be a great first read to get the bases covered.

Very interesting and well documented history about the divisions that of happened in our country since 1974. The book looked at leadership and politics, music and popular culture and showed how the opinions of the margins of society created divisions amongst all. From the beginning you can see the development of government we have today.

Great book. It's full of amazing details during the 70s, 80s and 90s explaining in detail how the conservative movement dominated the era, ideologically and politically and how the society got more and more polarized in social and economical issues. It got a bit hasty towards the end and skimmed through 2000-2017 though.

I found the book highly engaging. Although I was a child when earlier events occurred, I certainly remember most of the events. I recommend the book for anyone looking to refresh their memory of events in recent U.S. history (since the 1970s) and, perhaps, gain some perspective on how those events evolved to where we are today.

This was a very interesting review of the events occurring in our world and country since 1974 that have contributed to us becoming such a politically divisive society in the United States. The time period covers just over 75% of my life so it was particularly interesting since I recall the events.

More a personal quibble than anything wrong with the book. Since I lived through the history being recounted, I found it a little dull at times. I heard all these stories told in real time on the evening news or read them in newspaper and online. There was nothing new, at least for me. I had expected more insight into the deep divide.

A solid timeline of divisive events in contemporary American history. Never gets too deep, but makes for an introduction of sorts. Apparently, this was based on a course taught by the author and it kind of feels like an intro history course that you’d take as a freshman in college and you’d maybe sign up for more classes with that prof.

Good overview of the last 50 years of U.S. History (sobering to think that, as an undergraduate, I took U.S. History since 1945, and this is essentially the equivalent.) Having lived through this history, it is fun to be reminded of some of the trends and blood boiling to be reminded of others. As a survey, it was too superficial to be entirely satisfying.

Follows the ever increasing partisanship of politics from the 1970s to present day. While each generation likely feels that theirs was the most partisan, there are plenty of examples, many quite extreme, to go around. Well written and presents a fairly balanced viewpoint (IMHO).

Fascinating, essential reading. “Twitter’s Historian” Kevin Kruse and Julian Zelizer took their popular Princeton course and turned it into this well-written exploration of how the United States, especially since Watergate in 1974, has become a deeply divided country.

Quick moving summary of recent history and how we got to where we are today. Very assuredly shows how Trump is the latest symptom of fault lines that were largely blown open by Gingrich and McConnell.

The first two chapters and last chapter were too familiar to me and I was bored but the middle was great. I forgot a lot of what happened in the 70s and 80s and it was interesting to review. Very readable and a good summary of how we got to now and Trump.

How did we get here? Historians will wrestle with the answers to this question for many years, but Kruse and Zelizer’s early response is a fine jumping-off point. I’m putting this in the pile of books I might use the next time I reach the recent US history survey.

Exceptional. A clear and fairtheir political, social, or Travis strange explanation of the development of post-Watergate America. Everyone, regardless of their political, social, or racial beliefs, will enjoy and benefit from this insightful work.

I did think that it was very informative and I did finish it for that reason.

Easy and good read on US history (with strong focus on politics). The more I read about history, the more I realize we rarely learn from it. We simply repeat it in slightly different ways based on the time in which we are currently living.

A vast undertaking arising from a course taught at Princeton on the course of the history of politics and our government since 1974. Fair minded, all encompassing, and masterfully documented. And it leaves the future - as always - in our hands.

Compelling history of the USA since 1974. Kruse and Zelizer highlight political, economic and social divides that have formed and grown in the last decades. These divides are the result from technologies like the internet, cable news and growing partisanship.

Well researched and meaty with information, this is an important book. It traces the origins and arc of our failed social experiment with Prohibition. And beyond the solid history lesson, it unveils the enduring parallel history of "the war on drugs" that has its roots in the same misguided and discriminatory effort at behavioral control. A war marred by ethnic bias, selective enforcement, mass incarceration, and a tragic neglect of the underlying economic causes of drug dependency. Little appre

This is a fresh and original book that has something new to say about the so-called “noble experiment” and can even tie it to recent times. McGarr, a professor of history at Harvard whose previous book was “Suburban Warrior” (a look at the post-Goldwater conservative movement) look at the 1920s prohibition effort and notes two key ways that it changed the nation – then and ever since. The theme of the War on Alcohol, aka Prohibition, is that it was an era which set the tone for much of what we would see in America in coming decades. It established political alignments that exist to this day, expanded federal authority and even changed nightlife forever as the male bastion saloon was wiped out and replaced by the speakeasy, a nighttime gathering place for women as well as men.

She definitely points out some sides of prohibition that I had never considered before. Worth a read, esp if you’re interested in some of the (super) early origins of the war on drugs and the reach of the federal gov.

Lisa McGirr’s War on Alcohol provides an alternative view of prohibition, unlike the books and movies that celebrate speakeasies, clubs, flappers, elaborate private parties, and other aspects of the roaring twenties. McGirr focuses on the political and social history of prohibition and the 18th Amendment’s effects on poor communities and working class immigrants. Lisa McGirr is obviously well versed in the history surrounding the prohibition. In that regard this book is good... and therein lies the only good.

For those of us who view Thomas Jefferson as one of the greats in the pantheon of outstanding American Presidents, this book presents the unusual opportunity to share the insights of two eminent Jefferson scholars in exploring the mind of this extraordinary, if somewhat enigmatic, individual. The authors are like Aurigas at a Roman Triumphs whispering in the ear of the reader: " Momento homo "(remember he is (only) a man).

The constellation of Jefferson books are becoming more difficult to congeal into one story. Joseph Ellis had it right when he called Jefferson a Sphinx, but Gordon-Reed seeks to bring clarity to the mystery that is Thomas Jefferson. You may not agree with her perspective or conclusions, but it would be a mistake to ignore her book. Illuminating the heart of Jefferson like few others, her view is a necessity.

A very nuanced and balanced look at Jefferson's family life at Monticello. A scholarly read on the life and political development of Thomas Jefferson. Negative aspects of his life are also addressed as are contradictions. This biography focuses on Jefferson's personal life, his home, his family, and his attitudes about them. Thomas Jefferson has slowly lost the luster that surrounded him from my early years of High School and College. I don't think I really like the man. That said, this biography makes an earnest attempt to explain the man and I think it does a good job. Jefferson was a man of his age.

Calhoun, and Stephen Douglas. I enjoyed the detail.

This book might be compared to Robert Caro’s life of Lyndon Johnson.

Very thorough read, perhaps too thorough at times, but I learned a few things about Lincoln's life that I did not know -- quite a feat for a man that has been so well written about.

This is one of the more detailed history books I have ever read. This is the first in what will be a series of books that detail the political life of Abraham Lincoln. Countless books have been written about Lincoln, but what sets this book apart is the almost overwhelming details given about seemingly anyone of importance at the national and local (for Illinois and Washington, DC) levels during the years of the 1820s through the 1840s. One of the best political biographies (up there with Caro's on Johnson) and one of the best and most interesting I've read on Lincoln himself, this is a great read. Covering the 1830's and 40s not only do we read about Lincoln's development as a politician but also about the people and events of a too little known chapter of American History: Clay, Calhoun, Jackson, Douglas, the Mormons in Illinois, political patronage, the rise of the party system, etc. etc. I recommend it highly and look forwa

I was looking forward to a book about Abraham Lincoln. In the first five CDs, roughly half of the content has been about others. I can understand the details about his contemporaries and idols (e.g. Henry Clay) but I've just given up after an hour about John Calhoun. Perhaps the author would have gotten to the point about why Calhoun was an influential figure. I don't think the day-by-day political manipulations of the vice president (when Lincoln was a teen) were helping me understand Lincoln.

A good book, but a little too detailed. And also a little early in Lincoln's career to go into this much detail. Does a very good job of bringing the slavery debate and how divided the nation was at the time to light. I think the next book in the series may be more to my liking since it takes place closer to the time Lincoln became president. I will want to read that book, so I guess that says something for the quality of Blumenthal's writing.

This is volume 1 of Sidney Blumenthal's trilogy about Lincoln. This book, covering Lincoln's childhood through his Congressional career, contains more details--sometimes excruciatingly so--about this period of his life than I've seen thus far. Blumenthal's writing can sometimes be confusing, since he likes to pack as much information into one sentence as humanly possible. That said, the book is still a valuable resource for Lincoln-philes. I look forward to reading the next 2 volumes.

An absolutely fantastic exploration of the political engagements of Lincoln placed within a detailed and fascinating discussion of the politics of 19th Century America. The discussions of the role and influence of John C. Calhoun is quite enlightening, as is the surprising involvement of Lincoln with the Mormons. This is only volume 1 of what is to be a 5 volume work. I have now completed volumes 2 & 3, and have had a difficulty n putting these books down. They are superb and enlightening.

Overall I thought this was a good read. However, Blumenthal's very negative description of the Mormon prophet Joseph Smith comes across as bigoted and not consistent with the objective biographies that have recently been published about him. Made me wonder about the objectivity of the rest of his analysis.

Just not as focused of a book as I wanted it to be. Way too broad in scope and you lose track of where you are in the scheme of things. Also way too much block text of quotes said by others. Eventually it comes together but still not nearly the best biography I have read on this section of LIncoln's life.

Good overview of Lincoln’s early political life, which gives a detailed account of how he developed his political persona. Sometimes the detail becomes a little too discursive as the narrative moves away from the main actor and concentrates a considerable number of pages on other players in the political arena, but this has the compensating virtue of providing greater context.

This was a hard book to read. It was chocked-full of information and people, I had a very hard time keeping them straight!! Serious history buffs would love this book. I found it an accomplishment to have finished it.

Well researched, including things I hadn't read in other Lincoln biographies. Poorly written, long run-on sentences. Confusing sentences at time. I had been looking forward to reading this series, but gave up halfway through the second book. I will get back to it at some point.

Remarkable, well researched scholarship

This was the best book I have read on Lincoln. I feel like I have had a glimpse of who the man truly was, as well as an insight into what the United States and the historical figures of the time were like. I very much enjoyed the read.

This is a very different kind of book about Lincoln. It explains how he got to be the politician he was, and the forces that shaped his opinion of slavery. I'll be reading more of McCullough's work.

This is a great book on how to avoid your country falling into tyranny trap. It illustrates how oppressive regimes worked in the past and what should be done to avoid and crush them in the present and future. Taking examples from European politics in 1920s-1940s under authoritarian governments, it clearly shows that history does not actually repeat itself; it instructs. It instructs us to learn the lessons for our future.
